etymologies: late Middle English: Latin, from et ‘and’ and cetera ‘the rest’ (neuter plural of ceterus ‘left over’)

notes.text: Et cetera (a Latin phrase meaning ‘and the other things, the rest’) is sometimes mispronounced ‘ ex cetera,’ and its abbreviation, properly etc., is often misspelled ‘ect.’ The phrase ‘and et cetera’ is redundant, for et means ‘and’ in Latin. This abbreviation should be used for things, not for people. Et al. (an abbreviation of et alii, ‘and other people, and others’) is properly used for others (people) too numerous to mention, as in a list of multiple authors: Bancroft, Fordwick, et al. In general, both terms (and their abbreviations) are common enough that it is not necessary to italicize or underline them

definitions: used at the end of a list to indicate that further, similar items are included

examples.text: we're trying to resolve problems of obtaining equipment, drugs, et cetera

shortDefinitions: used at end of list to indicate that further items are included

definitions: indicating that a list is too tedious or clichéd to give in full

examples.text: we've all got to do our duty, pull our weight, et cetera, et cetera

shortDefinitions: indicating that list is too tedious to give in full

synonyms.text: and so on and so forth
